title: Patch Chat with the Playtest Team - 7.21
body:
https://news-a.akamaihd.net/public/na_images/PCHCHT/Minions.jpg
Header by inkiness

Hey, everyone! I'm Riot King Cobra and it's time for another round of Patch Chat! These threads serve as opportunity for us to talk about the patches that come out every two weeks. You can find the most recent patch by following this link: [Patch 7.21 Notes](http://na.leagueoflegends.com/en/news/game-updates/patch/patch-721-notes).

I'm a QA Analyst on Riot's Playtest Team, a group of high elo players who play with the new champions, reworks, balance tweaks, items, and map updates before they are released. It's our job to the test the changes that our designers come up with and ensure that we're introducing positive changes to League in terms of both balance and fun.

It's the last patch before preseason! As such, this patch is smaller than normal and features a slight tweaks to a number of champions. We're making adjustments to Galio, Sejuani, Rammus, Udyr, Urgot, and more. Additionally, we're knocking Ardent Censer down a peg and helping out Frozen Heart and Tear of the Goddess.  Ask us questions about the patch, or anything else you're interested for that matter. We'd love to talk with you guys. :)

Don “Aesah” Ding

As long as we're talking about rioter names... presumably the majority of rioters had league accounts before becoming rioters, so when hired did you just get to take your existing account(s) and stick riot_ in front, or do you get special riot accounts made independent of your personal account(s)?

Related, when a rioter leaves riot for whatever reason, do they get to keep the account and just be renamed to exclude the riot_ part, or do riot accounts have magic features (e.g. infinite RP/IP or something) that means they stay in company hands?

I think some people make new accounts and others just change their account name. Many Rioters also just don't take a Riot tag. And yeah, you keep your account but lose the Riot tag. No magic features :P.

1) have you guys thought of deleting maw and sticking hexdrinker on edge of night?

2) will we soon see anymore details about this new champion? I'm dying! 

3) in season 8 do you think assassins will see their burst speeds back?

1. No idea if this has been considered before, but the current version of Edge of Night doesn't have the same goals as Hexdrinker/Maw so I don't think that makes a ton of sense. In the past when Maw had pen on it (which would be what Hexdrinker->EoN would have to make sense), it was a problematic item, so I doubt that we'll see another pen item that builds out of Hexdrinker. 

2. I don't know when the next details will be out and we leave that to other teams that spend a lot of time working on teasers and such.

3. Unlikely. Assassin burst speed was reduced intentionally, so even though in some cases it probably could be upped some I don't think there's going to be any large overhaul bringing back assassin burst speed.

We are generally not happy with this sort of burst damage unless champions are far ahead, especially if it's the point and click variety. Given the multiplicative nature of AD carries damage however, I'd say some cases like this Vayne one are bound to pop up from time to time. We don't like this pattern for Vayne however, and made some changes to her a couple patches ago to remove the bonus damage from her Q adding to crits, and this was one of the primary reasons why.

Ultimately I think balancing the dps of all the different classes in the game is just a difficult needle to thread. Having fair damage amounts at all points in the game becomes difficult when the "burst" characters (assassins and mages) have flat damage via their spells and the "DPS characters have items like Infinity Edge and Statikk Shiv that can allow them to deal as much as 3x their normal auto attack damage.

What is the purpose of an assassin then, if it is not to burst? If they take just as long to deal the same damage as a marksman, is their mobility supposed to make up for the fact that they are melee and are harder to play? Doesn't seem like there's much incentive for the assassin player, to be honest. 

Not to mention, without assassins, marksmen are running amok and people are having a harder and harder time killing them.
Did any of you read the reddit post regarding arcane comet rune .. if the answer is yes what are your thoughts on it ?

Yes. I agree with parts of the post in that there are some mages who don't feel like they have as many options in the system as we'd like them to right now. That being said, I disagree with the evaluation that the Keystone is bad and I think it's actually pretty powerful. We've found this to consistently be one of the higher damage Keystones in our testing, and I think it's a fine catchall option for casters. 
We'll be keeping an eye on mage Keystones when things hit live and thinking about ways we can make those who are sad about the loss of DFT/TLD happy.
I look at comet and it just looks deeply unsatisifying as a Malz player. Has anyone tried Domination primary on him instead of running Sorcery?

If memory serves, there was a Rioter earlier saying that the Summoner Specialist keystone in the inspiration tree is ideal for him because the spells he wants in Lane are different from the ones he wants late game

I did mention last patch chat we'd theorized it to be good, though as far as I know no one has actually tried it yet. It's not just the ability to swap summoners, but also the huge amount of summoner spell CDR that Summoner Specialist offers that's really attractive for Malz.

Yeah this is the kind of sentiment we are keeping an eye out for, so thanks for voicing that. 
We are trying to make Arcane Comet more appealing to DoT mages like Malzahar by adding the cooldown refund for hitting champions with spells while Comet is on cooldown, allowing them to increase their DPS and proc it multiple times through landing multiple spells.
I can understand how this change may not be enough to those who are unsatisfied with the actual payout of the proc though.
Let me know how it feels once you've tried it!

hey, just out of curiosity, why is it okay for galio, with 96 AP and 5 ranks in Q, able to clear caster minions, but me on karma with 120 ap and 5 ranks in Q am unable to clear caster minions?

I can't remember the exact time slice it happened, but I know galio and I were about even on farm and around the 10-12 min mark. I just find it frustrating that a tank can wave clear better than a mage. :/

Well, there's a variety of reasons. It's not like all champions can (or should) have the same amount of waveclear, and obviously it's mostly dependent upon what the rest of the kit is, their strengths, weaknesses, etc. In Galio's case, he's a melee without a reliable trading pattern against ranged champions who has very punishable cooldowns. Without some amount of ranged waveclear he'd just get shut out of the game at any point where he fell behind, plus having high damage on the persistent part of the Q means he can have less poke (since champions can just walk away from the Q tornado) and more all-in pressure since he can use his cc to keep people inside the tornado. Galio is also making a conscious choice when he uses Q to clear backline - without it, he has no ranged abilities and has to commit his body to cs the melees and any ranged creeps he didn't kill, or to fight his lane opponent. 

It's also worth noting that Galio is not really a tank. On live (before this patch drops), he's played most effectively as full tank, but after this patch he should be more akin to an AP bruiser, though on the tankier side of those.
Out of curiosity, doesn't everything you just said about Galio apply to Fizz as well? Yet he doesn't have any ranged waveclear at all.

This is a complicated question that I probably won't answer as well as a designer could, but I'll give it a go.

Here's the short answer - a lot of the same things are true of both kits, but Fizz is a very different type of champion with different needs and different areas of power. Fizz has an enormous spike at level 6 in most matchups that gives him substantial kill threat on his lane. Galio, on the other hand, only has three abilities and no ultimate in a 1v1 - so a similar question to yours would be why can't Galio use his ult on himself to fight people 1v1? Same reason why Fizz doesn't have ranged waveclear - they're different champions with different strengths and weaknesses. 

The long answer to this question is complex and in some ways has to do with the play pattern of both champions. Fizz is an assassin, and Galio is somewhere between a bruiser and a tank. Even beyond that, Fizz is an extremely snowbally roamer who also has a lot of kill threat 1v1 in many matchups. Galio has relatively lower snowballing potential (though it is higher this patch with better AP ratios) and also has substantially lower kill threat 1v1. Galio typically plays through his sidelanes or jungler, even when he's ahead, whereas Fizz's success cases typically involve him being enabled by his sidelaners or jungler and then playing through his own lane or setting up his own plays afterwards. 

Okay, now what does that have to do with waveclear? Well, if Galio is less frequent/reliable/powerful (not sure how to properly phrase it - Galio generally can do less per game time) at initiating plays himself and has less options than Fizz to make an impact on the game, how is he compensated for that? One way is ranged waveclear.

Another way to frame it is, "what does Fizz look like with ranged waveclear?" He starts to be a lot more like Zed or Diana - more difficult to deny early on, more reliable, and as such the power in the rest of the kit (most likely E and/or R) has to be drained to support this new ability Fizz has. Part of why Fizz is allowed to have an untargetability that's also a double dash on a basic ability (one of the most powerful basic abilities in the game) is because he doesn't have ranged waveclear and generally falls behind in early lane.
What changed that made / allowed you guys to post so much more in the patch chat 7.20 compared to the other previous patch chats?

It's a combination of factors, but the main one is more playtesters are on the team now, so more people have free time to respond on Patch Chat. If you look at previous patch chats, you can see 7.17 is where the red post count starts to really go up, which was the first patch where all five of the new playtesters (myself, Ender L, Novalas, Auberaun, and GangIeri) were available to post. We started at about the same time and a huge percentage of the motivation to post more on Patch Chats has come from myself and Novalas. 

Increased playtester contribution to Patch Chat has gone over really well so it's something we're likely to continue doing as much as we can (within reason). Not to say we'll respond to every comment but we're definitely looking to communicate with community more, and Patch Chat is a good place to do it.

Have you considered a potential emergency scenario where you would have to revert runes reforged further down the line? What are your backup measures in case something absolutely game-breaking happened that would force the new runes to be taken out of action for several days or even weeks?

From a gameplay perspective, I can't see why we'd have to revert runes. We're definitely committed to supporting Runes Reforged going forward. Any potential emergency scenario would probably be from a technical end, and we don't really have insight into that end or contingency plans for those teams.

Do you think a lot of mid/high rank players will fall due to the new runes? Or will we perhaps get even more players in the higher ranks due to the increased focus on personal skill/playstyles as opposed to "generic all-rounder rune pages" that we've had for all these years?

######*example: i have a rune page with 24 armor and 8 attack damage to help me deal with heavy AD champions like Riven, Renekton and Pantheon when in an unfavourable matchup. I feel like the new runes will not allow this anymore - so if i pick, say, Camille top and get counterpicked by Riven, my early game will be extremely vulnerable with the new runes as opposed to the old ones.

Is there a possibility of increasing Azir's Q AP Ratio to compensate for the missing base damage? Lowering his Q ratio really took away from his fantasy of being a late game hyper carry. 

I personally feel like Xin benefited a lot more from his update than Azir but that Azir is being nerfed due to longstanding negative connotations that people seem to have with him when he does manage to find success.

Azir is still really strong late game! (Most of Azir's hyper carry damage comes from auto'ing with soldiers anyway)

We underestimated him in testing before the mini-rework, he was nerfed simply because his power level was too high. Inexperienced Azir players were winning almost 50% of their games, which is out of line considering how difficult he is to play.

So Since ardent has been nerfed, does this mean the mage supports will be able to come back and not be a complete hindrance to their teams?  
These past few patches have been really really harsh on Zyra, she struggles in the midlane so she was forced botlane then she got pushed out of botlane by the enchanting supports.  Basically im a Zyra main hoping i can pick her again without feeling like im just making the game harder for my team. 
(although im super hopeful for some Zyra changes to buff up her midlane a bit without touching her supporting too much)

Yeah I'd expect these champions to be a lot more viable after the Ardent nerfs. Doran's Shield is still a thing though, so I'll be interested to keep an eye out for how viable bot mages are in general. Runes Reforged will surely have a large effect bot as well, and I personally think it will make the strengths and weaknesses of Support mages sharper. You will deal more damage with Arcane Comet/Scorch than you do on live, but enemies also have the ability to specialize in lane sustain more via their runes than they could previously. Will be interesting to see which of these factors proves to be more impactful.

> [{quoted}](name=RiotMadnessHeroo,realm=NA,application-id=A7LBtoKc,discussion-id=zzhiQJFF,comment-id=000b0000,timestamp=2017-10-24T22:24:52.074+0000)
>
> You will deal more damage with Arcane Comet/Scorch than you do on live, but enemies also have the ability to specialize in lane sustain more via their runes than they could previously. Will be interesting to see which of these factors proves to be more impactful.

How does this math out with the huge hit to starting pen for Brand and Zyra? In terms of total harass over the course of a lane, Comet/Scorch might do more damage. 

What matters more is that lower pen means high EHP on the ADC and support, higher EH from all sources of healing, and higher EH from shields. If the strength of a support mage is bursting the carry, how does anything on PBE improve on live?

On live if you're an AD against a Brand/Zyra you would just always take flat MR blues. The net MR of their flat MR blues versus your Mpen Reds was in their favor by 4.3 MR (12.1 MR from 9x MR blues versus 7.8 Mpen from your 9x Reds). We are not touching champions MR in our base stat adjustments, so enemy AD's you face in lane will baseline have 4.3 less MR than they do currently on live. They can bridge this gap by taking Mirror Shell and most likely Second Wind paired with it, but they are giving up their entire splash and 2/6 of their pre-game rune choices to do this, whereas before AD's weren't really paying a significant penalty for running those MR Blues. 

So in total your baseline harass against AD's should be more potent in lane, but if they specifically rune against your harass it will likely be a little weaker. This is at an opportunity cost for them of both an offensive splash and taking Mirror Shell over Iron Skin meaning they'll be more vulnerable to your AD's harass. Add on things like Arcane Comet and Scorch and I think there's a strong case mage supports will be stronger, although there are counteracting factors like the loss of 2% damage from the Sorcery mastery.

I do think the responses to mage supports are fairly powerful though, and it will be important that we hit a spot where Second Wind/Mirror Shell + DSHield doesn't neuter these champions win condition entirely. It's also worth noting that most supports will have baseline less max HP as well due to the loss of flat HP yellows/quints, so they will be more susceptible to all-ins from Melee Supports unless splashing for Celestial Body in Inspiration, which does neuter their harass to some degree.

Also do you think nerfing Ardent again was the move?  I dont like enchanters and their minimal counterplay but Redemption already got nerfed as first item, if Ardent isnt viable either.. what do they get? 
I still think adc items are too cheap and spike too early tbh.

I'm of the opinion that enchanters don't really have a great early on option that feels like the right purchase after the ardent censer changes, which feels pretty bad as an enchanter player. On the other hand it was completely dominating support builds, support picks and even the ADC (Going targons) and I think something drastic was appropriate.

Right now, I don't feel particularly great about building Mikhail's (I miss the healing on cleanse ;_;) since it's pretty situational and unless I'm against a very high/impactful CC team I wouldn't really want to take it. I would expect this item to be more common purchase earlier, but I still think Redemption despite early nerfs would be the go-to as it has such a high teamfight/skrimish impact and at the time you finish it, it isn't all too nerfed compared to the previous version.  Athene's scales on mana regeneration, meaning that you would have to get a few mana regen items for this to unlock its fullest potential but it's pretty cheap at 2100 so I'm curious to see where this item ends up.
